page.title: 02NATIONAL TRUST, HIGH HAM
page.content: As well as its panoramic views over open countryside from the Mendips and Glastonbury Tor to the hills on the Somerset/Wiltshire border in the east, and across Sedgemoor to the Quantocks and Bridgwater Bay in the west, High Ham has 2 National Trust properties. Turn Hill, comprising 1.25 acres of grass and woodland at a height of 100m looking across the Battle of Sedgemoor fields to the Quantocks, was given to the N.T. in 1918 by Hugh & Beatrice Bellot in memory of their younger son, Bryson, killed in action. In 1969 their other son, Professor H. Bellot, left Stembridge Tower Mill to the N.T. It is open to the public on Sundays & public holidays,entrance fee 50p. Some 30 people visit the Mill each week. It was built in 1822 of blue lias stone with a thatched cap,unique in this country, and was in use until 1910.
